sentences_tone.text: Tesla: A Change Of Heart - Tesla Motors (NASDAQ:TSLA) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksTesla: A Change Of HeartNov.11.16 | About: Tesla Motors (TSLA) Ravi Bala Follow Growth, value, long/short equity, medium-term horizonSend MessageSummaryLoss of free charging signals a business model change.There is still customer capture despite the charges that may occur.The overall business model is now a Skimming model.I got a lot of colorful comments on my last article.
Quite normal since everyone assumes they are always right.
With the charging station officially not being free, Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) has incorporated the revenue generation portion of its business model that deals with the charging station.
No matter how silly the question, you need to ask yourself how the electric car will take off?
Now that the customer has to pay for charging, how much should Tesla charge customers?
Unfortunately, not many people drive electric cars compared to gas guzzlers since the electric car industry is still budding.
However, an interesting way to look at this issue is from Tesla's viewpoint.
They are trying to create a car for the mainstream public.
This means that we need to consider the cost of an electric charge versus tank of gas.
Thus, due to this modification of the electric charge business model, we need to consider this as an incremental service innovation.
The pricing strategy will ultimately matter the most to get potential customers to switch to electric cars.
Let's take a look at the current price of gas across the country.
Click to enlarge (Source: AAA) The average gas price is about $2.20 and the average tank for a small car is 12 gallons.
The average miles for a tank is 23.6, we will round to 25 for simplicity.
We want to look at this since Tesla's offerings are pretty limited for now.
For an average expenditure, it would cost approximately $26.4, with a total mileage of 300.
Not bad.
Now let's figure out what price Tesla could charge.
First, we need to take into account the average miles that can be driven on one battery charge.
Since the batteries come in many flavors, just eyeballing the chart on the different mileages, 250 seems quite reasonable.
(300 miles is for the most premium battery, so I did not consider it.)
I went to the US government energy website to find out an electric equivalent for gas prices.
They have a paper that goes over the methodology if you are really interested in understanding it better.
Click to enlarge (Energy.gov)
Based on the US average, the e-gas price is about 1.17.
Using the same average tank measure as a gasoline car.
If we assume that Tesla's cars and other electric cars in the future attain similar mileages as their gasoline tank counter parts, the savings seem to hold steady at 50%.
Interestingly, this chart below was from 2013 but the e-gallon prices have held constant despite the volatility in the regular gas prices.
We can extrapolate that despite the payment that will occur in the charge stations, it will not be enough to deter customers from switching to electric vehicles from gas vehicles.
Also, customers can expect there to be steady price increases or decreases.
Thus volatility in gas prices will be a thing of the past.
Despite the disappearance of free charging, the certainty of e-gallon prices is a value capture for customers who are thinking of making the switch.
In every business model, there has to be a revenue component otherwise, one would be unable to stay in business.
Though Tesla seemed to be changing the world, this announcement is quite telling.
Taking it one step further, we can conclude Tesla's overall business now employs a skimming business model, where the cars are pricey and the fuel is cheap, relatively speaking.
It similar to Apple's strategy with the iPhones.
This is in start contrast to the gasoline cars which apply the razor blade model, where the cars are cheap and the gas prices are expensive.
This may be a sign that Tesla has directed its attention towards profitability.
Welcome to capitalism Tesla!
Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours.
